div.head: DICTATORY.
div.p: The latest remarkable book portraying the conditions prevailing at the German Court is worthy of more than passing attention, because it is an important contribution to our knowledge of the Kaiser's personality and of the methods by which the greatest Continental Power is now being governed, writes a Berlin correspondent of the "Evening Standard and St. James's Gazette."

The author of "Our Emperor and his People : German Sorrows" who writes under the name of "Pessimist," dovotos part of his book to a description of William II. in personal intercourse, "Every one who sees our Kaiser for the first time," he writes, "is powerfully impressed by his strong personality. Williain II's frank, natural manners must necessarily captivate every one who comes into contact with him. His lively, expressive gestures, his loud, joyous laughs, exercise & unique charm. The Kaiser's bair is already grey, but his wonderfully intelligent blue eyes ook out upon the world with youthful fire. Like many other monarchs, he looks fixedly at an; one with whom he is in conversation, and those who are not accustomed to this stare easily become confused, thereby contributing to the mental predominance of the monarch. This is a device intentionally taught to royal personages during their upbringing."

The German Emperor, according to "Pessimist," however, does not need any auxiliary means to increase the effect of his own personality. He has genuine intellectual talents. Those who converse with him are struck by the originality and the wealth of his thoughts, by the versatility of his knowledge, and by the conviction with which he lays down his judgment. The impression which he invariably creates on other people is & source of pleasure to the Kaiser. It is such a pleasure that he continually experiences the desire to measure his strength with men of great mental ability. He has made a kind of sportof effecting the mental conquest of men of brains, and it is not a sport devoid of danger. William II forgets that however clever he may be he must always, overcome his intellectual opponent because Court etiquette prevents the other man from answering the Kaiser as he would reply to any other person. There can never be a fair trial of mental strength between the Kaiser and those whom he honours with his friendship. The Emperor, with all his great gifts, cannot divest himself of that additional authority which his imperial position confers upon him. Nor does he make any attempt to deprive himself of that advantage which he derives from his royal rank. It is impossible for him to place himself on a level with other men, for the simple reason that his conviction regarding the divine right of kings is an inherent part of his mental make-up. In the Kaiser's opinion it would be a violation of this divinity if he were to allow ordinary mortals to discuss controversial questions with him on & footing of equality. The consciousness of his divine inspiration places the Emperor, in his own estimation, above all criticism, and makes it very didicult for his official advisers to exercise any real influence on his policy. It is a curious fact that although the Kaiser associates with all sorts and conditions of men, he is less in touch with popular feeling than almost any other monarch of any civilised country. William II. receives scholars, manu. facturers, merchants, painters, inventors, posts, and sportsmen, Jews and Gentiles, thereby creating the impression that he is keenly alive to the varied interests of all classes of the nation, whereas in reality tris inborn feeling of superiority derived from divine inspiration makes it impossible for him to reap the advantages which might otherwise accrue to him from his intercourse with so many men of thought and action. The Kaiser is not only absolutely intolerant of any form of direct or indirect criticism, but easily becomes impa. tient when views of which he disapproves are expressed to him. The conviction of divine inspiration also leads the Emperor strenuously to hold to any opinion which he has once formed, however erroneous that opinion might appear to be to all competent judges. The result isbat William II. commits himself with surprising suddennesy to regrettable deci. sions and takes up untenable positions with excessive haste. The Kaiser's peculiar mental attitude prevents men of independent opinions from exercising any influence over him, whereas those skilled courtiers who can adapt them. selyes to the Imperial theory of the divine right oi monarchs are able, by subtle flattery, to gain the Kaiser's ear. The Kaiser's feeling of superiority is thus the cause of all those court intrigues of which so much has been written during these last few weeks. Moreover, it leads him to consider himself an expert authority on all manner of subjects. He lays down the law on intricate points of engineering, shipbuilding, agriculture, architecture, the art of sculpture, etc., as though he had devoted a lifetime of study to each one of these subjects, whereas he only possesses the superficial knowledge of an amateur. The author considers this to be a misfortune both for the Emperor him. velf and for his subjects. Much discontent is created owing to the fact that the Emperor imposes his decisions on masters of art, science, and invention when it would be more advisable to leave such matters to really expert authorities.

The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Purt Suid is expected to arrive at Alexandris to morrow morning, and will be distributed at th Q.P.O. at 8 a.m.

div.head: The Pllgrimage.
div.p: At yesterday's pletary meeting, the Qairan upe Board appointed Dr. Way to accompany tha Egyptian pilgrims, and inspect the quaruntine camp at Jeddah, owing to the quarantine against Egypt.
Train Acoldent

A shocking accident is reported from Etieh el Baroud, near Dimanbour, where two native Women were run over by a train, One of them was enceints, and had a leg severed. The other escaped with slight injuries.
Church of Scotland.

A sals of work in connection with the St. Andrew's Church branch of the Women's Guild will be held in the Scotch High School, Missala quarter, on Saturday, 15th inst, at 3 p.m. The object of the sale is to raise funds for the lighting of the rooms in the shool used by the church and guild, and to meet necesitous cases.
Wrestling at the Alhambra.

The following are the results of the bouts last night. Mobimed best Noel (16 ninotes); Limqosin bat Sundorfy (43 minute); Oct. tinger beat Eigmann (7 minutes); 8-backmann beat Finiach; B. zz rini baat Cylis (7 minates). The last boot was a fine chaw, both being eqally matohed, but Cylis, suprised at Erzzarini's prowess, lost confidence.
The Affray with Soinalis.

On Monday morning, the Court of Summary Justice of Port Said heard the trial of the Arabs concerned in the assault on Samslis. The Court sentenced over to six month, two to three month, and five to or month's
imprisonment. Of the Somslis, the have been sentenced to one month's imprisonment
by the British Consolar Court.
Winter Season In Ramnich.

The Ramleh winter season has now commenced and the hotels are beginning to fill with guests who are in search of health giving breezes. The New. Victoria Hotel, San Stefano, under the management of Mr. C. F. Risig, which was opened in June last and has been fall up during the whole summer season, will remain open during the winter monthy, and offers special terms for residents and tourists alike. Among the guests staying there we notice : Mr. James Watson, of Alexandria, Mr. James Carol Wilonek), Mr M C. Smith, Capt. R A. Lowthér, Mr. and Miss G. Gorra.
Court Martial.

Before a general court-martial held at Khartoum on 3rd October, 1906, El Mulazim Tani Mohamed Effendi. Kamel, 9 h Sudanese, was arraigned on the following charge :-- Committing a civil offence, that is to say; criminal misappropriation of property, in that the at Shambé, between the 22nd October, 1905 and 1st November, 1915, dishonestly min.p propriated four elephant 'luoks. 'l Coort found ihe prisoner guilty of the charge and sentenced him to be dismissed from His Highness's Service and to be imprisoned for six calendar months. By command of the Khedive the Sirdar has confirmed the finding aid sentence, but has remitted be imprisonment awarded.
All Saints', Cairo

We learn from the All Saints' Church Magazine that at the annual meeting of the church committee, the accounts were presected and passed, subject to audit. The report of the Antoin Yusef Charity Fund was read and discussed. During the year ending September 30th, the sum of £66.184.61 had been expended, and 13 cases assisted. Some discussion was held concerning the repairs of the church. Lord Cromer then announced that Dean Butcher had given notice of his resignation, to take effect in April. Unanimous regret was expressed by the committee, and it was determined to call & general meeting further discussion of the subject. This has since been held.
Merchant Seamen's Home.

The conrert at the Merchant Home last Friday night was a great success. Mr. and Mrs. Gilmour delighting the audience by their performance on the piano and the former by his violin so'os. Apart from the concert was fully carried out by officers, engineers and other from the ships then it harbour. Captain Lister making an excellent chairman. Sélections on the vio in by Mr. Mitchell, a passenger on the S. Egyptian Prince, we much anticipated, as low ra sa'ption 16* and cline by Mr. Prolo (SS Trinity) Jack Dunn, the 'monie" from the S.S. Cty if Cambridge caused much uchtar and encore. Songs by Mes, Poole, Merley. Eason Soffout, and Edwards were much enjoyed as
was the rendering of a fine song on the gram phone by one of the crew of the S.S Seti, The singing of the National Anthem brought a pleasant evening to a close at 10.45 p.m.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: THE "TIMES". ALLEGATIONS.

Most of our readers are probably aware of the allegations made recently in the "Times" in regard to his Highness having subscribed largely to the forthcoming production of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's European newspaper with funds derived from traffic in decorations,

The accusations therein contained are of such Lature that we can pronounce no immediate opinion as to their value. As a newspaper we are not in a position to investigate the truth or falsehood of what has been alleged, but we certainly incline to the belief that, provided that the report as to his Highness's denial is accurate, he has been totally misrepresented:

As to the Khedive's relations with the Nationalist Press, we understand that his Highness absolutely denies that any such relations exist. The statements contained in the "Times" are of such a character that it is difficult to disprove or prove them. Furthermore it must bo remembered that the Khedive, in his position as a Sovereign, is quity incapable of taking the ordinary course open to a private individual who feels himself aggrieved by a statement of such a type. On the other hand, the words of the late Sir Clinton Dawkins, which are quoted by the Cairo correspondent of the Times," have weight today. If some members of the ultra-Nationalist Press were rendered unable to claim his Highness's support with such persistence the opinion generally of the native public and the tone of the native Press (would be considerably modified. What is more serious in the statements that have appeared in our London contemporary is as to the purchase of grades and decorations. We trust and believe that his Highness is ignorant of the abuses of his exalted prerogative, which, so it is said, exist among some members of his entourage, and no doubt he is ignorant that his name is being used for this purpose. That this abuse exists is known to many persons, and we trust that in future decorations will be bestowed for merit alone by the Khedivé, and the sooner this is recognised the better. As to the other remarks of the "Times" correspondent, we do not believe that they were made with any malicious intent, but as it is said that his Highness has categorically denied the accusations brought against him, we sincerely hope that means will be taken whereby his good name will be entirely rehabilitated.
The following is an extract from the "Times" leading article: --

"Mustapha Kamel himself is not only once more in full favour at the Palace, but he is also once again in cash. Whether these alleged: facts are connected or not we cannot, of course, affirm, but it is suspected at Cairo that they are-in other words, that'no small portion of the money to be devoted to the new enterprise of the most bitterly Anti-British organ in Egypt iş furnished by the Prince who owes his position to British troops and his prosperity to British Administration. At any rate, the advanced Nationalists are speaking of the Khedive as the principal supporter of their programme. We cannot of course say to what extent, if at all, his Highness may be privy to the use which is being made of his name. But it is hard to suppose that he is entirely ignorant on the subject, and quite impossible to suppose that if he is not ignorant his name is being used against his will. ...."

On the subject of the sale of decorations the "Times" writes : "What is quite certain is that the trade in honours for hard cash' has of late assumed immense proportions in Egypt. Even in the worst days of Ismail that particulay form of corruption was unknown. But nowàlays it is rampant. Sime months ago a correspondent who had 40 years' intimate acquaintance with Egypt wrote: to us : Today titles of pashas and beys might almost be quoted on the Stock Exchange. The brokers are editors of rival native papers, the purchasers are anyone who for business or social purposes will pay the price, and the seller is the Khedive. That is a scandal which cannot be indefinitely tolérated, if only for the sake of our own good name. So long as British influence prevails in Egypt, the Egyptian fountain of honour, as an Egyptian whose own title had been honourably acquired observed to the correspondent, should be as absolutely above suspicion as our own."

The Khedive spent yesterday and today on his estates at Ismailia. To-morrow he will prob. ably return to Abdeen, and on Friday, attend prayers in El Shafi Mosque. In the evening his Highness will give a farewell banquet to M. Mitskens, Belgian Diplomatic Agent, who has been transferred to Rome, the other guests including the Ministers, M! Eid, Belgian Consul, and other notables of the Belgian colony On Friday afternoon his Highness will pay a visit the Tombs of the Khedives. On Saturday his Highness will preside at
The ceremony of the Keswat, or transfer of The Holy Carpet to the Mosque of El Hussein.

div.head:
THE S.S. NEGHILLEH.
STILL AGROUND.
div.p: (From OUR CORRESPONDENT.).

Suez, Tuesday. The Khedivial steamer Callioubieh, which was dispatched on Sunday last to assist the S.S. Negbilleh, which is ashore at Gemsah, returned to Suez this forenoon and reports being unable to move the stranded steamer. I underatand the company is about to send another of their steamers of more powerful capacity to Gemsah.
The position of the Negbilleh is apparently unchanged.

div.head: SINAT DELIMITATION.
div.p: ( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT. )
Suez, Tuesday. H.H.S. Aida is railing from Suez tomorrow for Tabah, in order to convey officials to complete the frontier delimitation.

div.head: AL AZHAR
div.p: It is stated on good anthority that Sheikh El Sberbini will retire from the presidency of Al Azhar on the expiration of his leave, and that the Khedive favours the appointment of Shekh Hag-oona El Nawawi to that vacancy. The report of his penchant for Sheikh Shokir is inexact.

It is also announced that the post of Chan. cellor of Al Azhar will entail with it that of Mofti. It this is 80, Sheikh Hassouna El Nawawi will be onable to fill it, owing to his state of health. Among other candidates is Sheikh Abou El Padl, whose old-fashioned ideas recommend him.

div.head: MORE RUMOURS.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" confirms the news that Mr. Mitchell Innes will be appointed to a high post connected with the Council of Ministers.

"Alhram" states that rumours are current in Government circles that Kassim Bey Amin, ot the Cairo Native Court of Appeal, will be appointed Minister of Justice; Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, will have a new post of Adviser to the Khedivial Maieh ; Fathi Bey Zaghloul, judge in the Native Court of Appeal will be appointed secretary to the Legislative Council, instead of Hossein Bey Yousry, who, after retiring on pension, will act as permanent member in the same Council.

div.head: TECHNICAL INSTRUCTION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Wills, who was appointed by the Egyptian Government to study the possibiliiy of generalising technical instruction in the model workshops, has returned to London, after having presented his report to the Ministry of Public Instructions. Mr. Wills was here for four weeks ; and he will return by the end of this month Previous to Mr. Wills' visit, the Government had intended adopting the Casanova method.

div.head: IMPORTANT NEW COMPANY.
div.p: Among the many and various companies which are to be floated in the course of this month is an important industrial concern, Caffari's Co operative Markets, Limited. The capital of the company is £40,000, in 39,725 Ordinary shares of £1 each and 5,00 Founders' shares of 1s, each. The chairman of the board is Mitre Emi o Manosardi, and the board is composed of Menara. Paul Ozio, Charles Grandjean, Philip Garozzo, Jules Schutz, and John B. Caffari. The manager in Cairo is Mr. Lawrence Menny and in Alexandria Captain Joseph Naponelli. A Founders' share will be given with every ten Ordinary shares allotted. The profits will be distributed as follows: 10 % to the board, 5% to the staff, 20 % to the Ordinary shareholders, 20% to the holders of Founders' shares, and 45% to the registered customers adherents of the company.

div.head: RITZ HOTELA.
div.p: We hear that the capital of the Ritz Hotels of Egypt, Limited, has been subscribed 35 times over.

div.head: THE STOSCH.
div.p: Herr Wunderlich, German Consul at Alexandria, gave a dinner yesterday evening to the officers and cadetes of the training ship Stosch at the Khedivial Club.
This morning Captain Hollefon, the comman lant of the Stosch, left for Cairo, where ha will be granted an audience by the Khedive at Abdeen Palace.
The cadete of the Stosch who went for a trip to Cairo returned on board yesterday.
The Stosch sails on Tuesday.

div.head: BANQUET TO M. PHILON.
div.p: In hononr of his appointment to be Hellenio Diplomatio Agent at Cairo, M. Philon was entertained this week at a banquet given by M. Gryparis, the Hellenic Minister at Constantinople, at which the members of the Legation and Consulate General ware present. At dessert, M. Gryparis, in a farewell toast, desired M. Philon to present his compiments to the Hellenic colony of Cairo and Alexandria, whose principal members were so helpful to him in the accomplishment of his mission in Egypt. M. Philon is going first to Athens, before coming to Cairo.

div.head: New Insurance Law.
div.p: The British Chargé d'affaires, Mr. Barclay has lodged an official protest with the Grand Vizier against the new Ottoman Insurance Company Law, the prescriptions of which are such as to debar all farther possibility of British insurance companion doing business in Turkey. The Grand Vizier replied that he would reconsider the matter and inform the British Embassy of the Porte's final decision.

div.head: Salt Contract.
div.p: Tue Marquis Theodoli, Italian delegate on the Board of the Ottoman Public Debt, lately secured the contract for the supply of 500.000 tons of salt to the Government of India. This was to have been obtained from the salt works at Salif, in the Yemen, but owing to the outbreak of smallpox there, the Debt have decided to ship the salt from Phoces.

div.head: Personal,
div.p: The Armenian press of Constantinople announces the betrothal of Count d'Arshott, Councillor of the Belgian Lagation here, and the daughter of Boghog Pasha Nabar. The betrothal took place at Nice, where also the marriage will take place sbortly.
M. Lahowary, of the Roumanian Parliament, who was lately in Alexandria, is now in Constantinople.

div.head: RAIN IN THE DESERT.
div.p: After seven years' drought good rain has

fallen all over the Nabian Desert between Keneh and Assouan and up to the Red Sea coast. This is of great importance to the various mining concessions in that district as it opens the tracts for getting about.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY CHANGES.
div.p: According to the "Standard," it is contemplated to redace some of the Egyptian native mounted troops now that a British cavalry regiment; a mounted detachment, and a horse battery form part of the white garrison.

The suggestion is to reduce to a lower etablisbment some of the Upper Egypt native horsemen. In addition, says our contemporary, the British Military Mounted Police Squadron is being recalled. This will leased the military debt. Major General Biden Powell is under orders to report upon the mounted troops in the country.
The native mounted forces consist of four Ezyptian and one Sudanese squadrons, three Arab camel companies, one mile and pony company, and one Arab (Kassala) battalion.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS.
div.p: The new tram line to Chonbra will be finished and working in a few weeks' time.

The line from the Bonlac railway workhops to the Cairo station is almost complete and is only awaiting for the railway crossing to be passed. The line from Bonlac along the Boolac road to the railway workshops is finished and will be in working order in a month's time.
The line to the Slaughter Houses, & prolongation of the Khalig line, will be finished next year.
Negotiations are now proceerding with the Ministry of Public Works for be line along the new Boulac Bridge.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA KUTTABS.
div.p: In response to an invitation of the Governor of Alexandria, & number of native notables of the city met on Monday at the Gouvernorat to consider the question of the local kuttabs. His Excellency delivered a specch on the subject, suggesting that a committee should be formed to look after the existing kattabs and take the necessary measures to improve their sanitary condition ; and to establish new kattabs in the quarters where they are needed. Suitable sites for the proposed kuttabs, said his Excellency, would be grantedly the Government. The committee was formed and a subscription was opened, the donations amognting to L B. 500. Ahmed Yehia Pasba, Hassabo Bey Mohamed, Ramadan Eff Yongsef, and Ibrahim Eff. Sid Ahmed each promised to build a kuttab at his own expense.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS:
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Malta yesterdry at noon, and is due here on Friday afternoon with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. British Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterdıay, and is due at Alexandria on Sattor lay morning.
The Elleman liner Adalia sailed this morning for Mauchester direct with a full cargo, including 9,819 bales cotton.

div.head:
1907 RACING SEASON.
A. S. C. NOMINATIONS.
div.p: The following are the nominations for the next racing season, 1907, which closed on 1st December :
FIRST SUMMER MEETING.

CLUB STAKES. --Pricne Omar Pasba Tongson's Hadban and Baylan, Capt. G. Gill-on's John Peel Saleh Bey Yagben's Cicero and Mystère, Ishack Bey Hussein's Padaan and Nadim, Capt. Rome and Capt. Grant's Rainbow, Omar Bey Saltan and Bakri Bey's Kohilan T-ir, Mr. B. Karam's Atbara and Val d'Or, Megers, A.J. Sarsook and A. J: Michaelides' Karoo and Phiptias, Baron J. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Italian warship Calabria ia due at Snez from the East in the latter part of this month, with H.R.H. Ferdinand of Savoy, Prince of Udino, on board.
Mustapbá Pasha Febmy, the Prime Minister, is still confined to bed with indisposition.
M. Philon, the new Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 15th inst.
M. Bmpain will arrive in Egypt towards the end of this month.

The death took place at Suez on Sunday, at the age of forty two, of Aly Bay Hagds, one of the wealthiest residents there. Over a thousand people attended the funeral, and among them Abdel Rahman Bey Mohamed Iskander, ex Sultan of the Maldive Archipelago.

Among the passengers from Marseilles by the S.S. Niger yesterday were Countess Morro-Morice. Mrs. Gibson, Mr. Giglic, Mme. Campos, M., Mme. and Mile Alby, M. de Salignas, M. Sursock, M. de Z gheb, Comte de Zogheb, Mr. Vervier, M. and Mne de Sérionne, M. and Mme Lorat, Mr. Curtis, Mme Poucet, Mme and Mile Abro, M. and Mme Mugner.
Baron and Baroness de Pitner and family bave engaged apartments at the New Victoria Hotel for the whole winter. They will shortly arrive there.
Mr. James Carol Wilcocks has left Alexandria and taken up his winter quarters at the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh.

Mr. A.O. Lamplough has once more returned to Cairo, and is giving a small exhibition of his sketches at the National Hotel next week. He is singularly happy in his rendering of Egyptian scenery and its translucent colouring; and those who remember his work of last year will be glad to koow of bis arrival. Mr. Limplough held an exhibition in Duke Street, St. James', London, last Jone, which was in every way a success ; and he is already at work seeking studies for his forthcoming show in London next summer.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: The following is the text of a letter addressed by Saad Pa ba Zagbloul, tbe now Minister of Education, to Yacoub Pasha Artin, late Under Secretary of State to that Ministry :

Excellence. - J'ai l'honneur de vons informer que Son Altesse le Khédive, tenant compte des conaidérations d'Age et de santé que vous avez invoquées dans votre lettre de démission de Sous Secrétaire d'Erat au Ministère de l'Instruction Publique, d'ée du ler novembre conrant, a accepté avec regret catte démission ; et que, en reconnaissance des immenses services que vous avez rendus an pays et principalement à l'Instraction Publique pendant les 32 antées que vous avez survi le Gonvernement Egyptien, il vous & accordé la décoration de l'0 mauieh, 1re classe.
En vous transmettant le brevet et les in signes de cette haate distinction si méritée, je vouz prie d'accepter mes biens sincères félioitations.
Je saisin, en outre, cette occasion pour vous dire combien je regrette personnellement votre décision qui me prive de votre collaboration si éclairés.
Je constats, toutefois, que la tâche qui m'est co fiếa sera grandement facilitée par les progrès réa'isés daos l'enseignement sous votre babile direction.
Je snis hearenx de vous exprimer les vifs santiments de reconnaisance du Ministère de l'Instruction Publique pour l'ovre que vous avez accomplie, pour le plus grand bien da pays.
Veuillez agréer, Excellence, l'expression de mon plus profond respect et de ma très haute considération.

div.head: PLAGUE AND SALINE SOLUTION.
div.p: We have received a long contribution from Dr. Rahmet (Samallout) on the stimulant properties of sult solution in plague. Although the ufio physiological - style of the writer is crade to the extreme it is oteworthy to find that an Egyptian doctor reads so much and takes such an interest in research. With regard to the main point, timely, the stimulant properties of sollution, they are well koown. to all clinicians, and there can be no doubt that in certain cases they may be useful in plague-colapse as in every other form of collapse. No doubt the injections most have been tried by many physician's, as they have been tried for every disease under the sun. Our experience is that they may be of use at the moment, but do no permanent good. The letter is too technical to be of general interest.

div.head:
MOROCCO CRISIS.
SPANISH MINISTRY'S RESTORTION.
FRANCE AND SPAIN IN AGREEMENT,

div.p: Senor Morat's Ministry has resigned in consequence of Parliament's disapproval of his having secretly written to the King in terms unfavourable to his own leader, Senor Dominguez. This splits the Liberal party, and will probably open the way for a return of the Conservatives to power.
Later. Marquis Vega de Armijo, Liberal, has been elected Prime Minister. General Weyler will be Minister of War.
The King has received. Admiral Touchard. This audience had been delayed on account of the Ministerial crisis.
(Reuter)

M. Pichon announced to the Council of Ministers the despatch of a note to the signatory Powers of the Algeciras Convention informing them of the complete agreement between France and Spain in regard to their common action in Morocco. (Havas)
Senor Vega de Armijo has recbaatitated the Cabinet. .
M. Cambon presented Admiral Touchard to the King. The interview lasted for an hour.
The Spanish squadron has been placed under the orders of Admiral Touchard. (B.)

CAPITULATIONS IN BULGARIA.
POWERS AGREE TO ABOLITION:
All the Powers have agreed to the abolition of the Capitulations in Bulgaria. This is tentamount to the recognition of the independece of the Principality.
(Reuter)
House of Lords -- The report stage of the Edacation Bill has been concluded with farther amendments which are unacceptable to the Government.
(Reuter)
House of COMMONS -The Plural Voting Bill was read for the third time and adopted by 333 votes to 104.
(Reuter)
The Persian delegates have been authorized to remove to Mossul for the winter, and to continue the negotiations with regard to the delimitation of the frontier. (Reuter)

REICHSTAG.-Herr Dernburg, amid laughter and' uproar, defended the Colonial administration. The Socialists renewed their charge, demanding punishment of the superiors besides the subbordinates. Herr Dernburg promised to punish the guilty and protect the innocent.
(Reuter)
The Pope has informed the Poles that he sympathizes with them, but cannot expouse their cause in opposition to Germany. (Reuter)

div.head: ARMY, AND NAVY.
div.p: Farther reinforcing drafts for the cavalry Royal Artillery, and infantry in Egypt will leave Southampton by the S.S. Braemar Caste on the lst December. The same liner, wil convey the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fasiliers from Alexandria back to Malta, from where it was withdrawn during the Tabah crisis, and the 1st Battalion Royal West Kent Regiment from Malta home, for Dover. This in accordance with the ameaded programme of reliefs.
In March next, Lieutenant Colonel C. J. Markham, King's Royal Rifle Corps, will complete three years at the head of the let Battslion, Cairo, and in the usual course will is promoted brevet colonel,

Captain F. S. Maude, CMG., D.S.0., from second in command of the lstt Battalion Coldstream Guards, has been formally appointe Deputy Assistant Adjutant and Quarter master General on the staff of Major General Sir J. Leash, K.C.V.O, commanding at Plymouth, vice Major A. S. Dunlop. Royal Artiliery, - Mujor Maad, who is the son of the late Ganeral Sir F. F. Maude a Crimean and Indian veteran, served with distinction in the South African War, being in tha march of the Guards from the Modder to Kimberley, Bloemfontein, and Pretoris, and the hard fighting en route (mentioned in des patohes, D.S.O., Quen's medal with six clasps); and as sub, he saw a bit of tough work against the Mahdi's fighting man in the early 'eighties' including the sharp action of Hasheen and the retractios of Temai (medal with clasp and Khedlive's star)

The offers of bonties of various amounts to men of the disbanded line battalions to induce them to transfer to other regiments has not provod a success, the rank and file showing a commandable esprit de corps in sticking to) their old regiments. Tommy Akins is in herently & Conservative, and cares not for the chopping and changing of the War Office.

blue (in R fle regiment green) patrol-jacket, as described in paragraph 739, Dress Regulations 1904, but without gorget patches. The re-introduction of this jacket has been sanctioned in order to save the wear of this frockcoat. Its provision is optional and it is not to be worn on duty nor when parading with troops. The pattern will be universal for all branches of the service and will hear no distinctions other than badges of rank. The jacket of Highland regiments may be cut away in front to clear the sporran. This decision does not affect the service dress of Staff officers and Officers Commanding Volanteer Brigades, the Goards, and Royal Malta Artillery.

A gun breech has been invented in America for converting heavy orduance into very rapid firers with assured safety. The invention prevents accidental explosions and "flare-backs" It comprises a screw pin attachment operated by compressed air, which blows all gases from tha bore, and cleans, and cools, and labricates the rifling. The invention has been tried at Sandy Hook successfully.

During her recent gunlayer's tests the cruiser Argyll made some record shooting. From one of the 75 turret guns, Chief Petty Officer F. Chapman scored thirteen hits in thirteen rounds in the marvellously short period of one and three quarter minutes. This constitutions world's record for the 7.5. Another gunlayer, Chief Patty Officer Behannanah, scored eleven hits in as many rounds in the same time.

div.head: GOUVEŘNEMENT DU SOUDAN
div.p: Concessions de Terrains & Batir
a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan, va prochainenent disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'en riron 400 parcelles de terrains & batir & Port Boudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail mphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années d partir du ler Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer sinuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le oyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuite noyennant uş toyer variable fixé à la fin de haque terme soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des pâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas Considerée comme un motif d'augmentarion de loger.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est buée pour une durée de 80 années à prtir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, l'exapiration le ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir in nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 30 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux amphytéotiques dont s'agit; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement a la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues a Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécifica tion du bail, seront i la disposition du Public À partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T)et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.

div.head: GORDON COLLEGE
div.p: A RECORD OF THE YEAR'S WORK.,

Ms Carrie, Director of Edacation in the Sudan, in the fifth annual report on the working of the Gordon Memorial College at Khartoum, states that, so far as it is possible to judge, progress during the past year has been ominently satisfactory, No fresh departures have been taken, but the development of the existing scheme proceeds ap On account of the very rapid development to country it is utterly impossible to supply bad twentieth of the demands that are made for employees by the various Government Departments. This fact is mentioned in order to attempt to reassure critics whom nothing seems able to convince that the Gordon College is not an institution for the manufacture of superfluous clerk- superfluous and therefore discontented. A more practical questtion is whether the Sudanese boys now being turned out are reasonably effiicient and honest. The chief employers of the boys have been so far the Director of Posts and Telegraphs and, on a much larger scale, the Director of Sarveys. It is encouraging to be able to say that both these officers give a distinctly favorable report on the boys in their service. The vast majority appear to be doing their work honestly and intelligently. The Cadete of the Military Shool, some thirty in number, who receive their location in the Primary School, continues to make good progress. The Training College has prospered. It now numbers nne hundred and five students, and ten young Sheikhs have now completed their fifth and final year of training: They begin work in October five in the Mohamedan Law Courts and five in various schools. There is no doubt whatever that the examination papers of the young Arabs exbibt an intelligence and promise of a kind that would be noteworthy in any country. Whether they will, when they enter on their professional work, show themselves proof against the evil, obsscurantist, and fanatical doctrine that will assuredly be from time to time preached to them remains to be seen. A beginning was made with the secondary school in October last with a staff of three English masters. The pupils, sixteen in number, have been divided into two sections. The first section will go through a training, that will be of four years' duration. The object aimed at is to turn out a young men who will not be an engineer but a skilled overseer of the type found so usefl by the Public Works Dapartment in India, and who is for the most part trained at the Roorkee Engineering College. The second, or surveyor's section, will go through a course of training that will last for two years. The object is to turn out a set of men possessing a good koowledge of the elements of surveying, while at the same time they are sufficiently versed in English to take instructions and to write intelligible reports in that language. This scheme of higher instruction, like much else in the College, cannot yet be judged. So far as paper work is concerned the results of the eximinations at the end of thie year were far ahead of anticipation. It is difficult to exaggerate the extent or usefulness of this school should the product prove

If they cannot be trained localy, they will have to be imported from Egypt or the Levant at a cost to which in the aggregate it seems impossible to assign any limit. Good reports have so far been received on the boys hat have left the instructional shops and began work under normal conditions of artisan labour. The additional wing to the College for which the money was found by the Sudan Government some fifteen months ago, was began in January and will be in fall use by the beginning of next year.
The Laboratorios : an Appeal.

Mr. Currie, in conclusion, draws attention to the liberal manner in which the Sudan Government are contributing to the support of the college. The Sudan Government's contribution towards the annual expenditure amounts to L.E. 12,000 per annum, and it has just made itself responsible for the pensions of the staff. "I am aware," he continues, "that Khartoum nowadays cannot expect to focus interest on itself in the manner of ten years ago, but if private munificence could be persuaded to render the College further aid in one direction a rich reward would be reaped. I allude to the laboratories. At present they are housed in the College in rooms which, thought perfectly suitable for present purposes, are not capable of very much extention. If they could be better housed their possibilities of usefullness would be much extended. The cost of such housing, with all accessories would amount, I have ascertained, to something between L. B. 15.000 and L E 20 000, and from the results of the work thus rendered possible the whole world might expect to benefit. Though I have never hesitated to ask the Sudan Government for substantial help, and they have never yet refused it, they are doing their duty to the fall by the laboratories already, and I am in no sense whatever justified in looking to them for help in this matter."

div.head: THE COTTON POSITION.
div.p: THE INCREASE IN THE AMERICAN SUPPLY.

Messrs. Neill Brothers in their review of the cotton position dated Nov. 22, state : Shipments have made good progress, both to Great Britain and the Continent, the total exports sice September 1st having now reached 1%,244 000 balon against 2,018,000 last year and 2 612,0 0 in 1904.

Thus the takings of English and Continental spinners are keeping wonderfully close to those of last year ; but as regards this country it is of some significance to note that the Board of Trade returns for the two months of September and October show exports of yards only 33,536000 lbs. against 36,136,000 last year, a reduction of, say, 7 per cent, and of goods only 994,335,000 yards, against 1,086,650,000 last year, & reduction of 5 per cent. These figures, so far as they go, show less activity in the export trade of Manchester, and make it doubtful whether those people are wise who reckon upon & season's takings of American cotton in excess of last year's total of 12,004 000 bales.

"A very liberal deduction for possible overestimate of mill stocks would still leave a supply for 1916-7 of over 15,000 000 bales, against a consumption probably not much, if at all, over 12.030,000, leaving 3,000,000 bales of American to carry over into bext your, not to mention the large crops also coming from Iodia aod Egypt ! Of these 15,000,000 bales there will surely be enough good spinners' cotton to make any anxiety 48 to the season's supply entirely out of place, although it is, of course, true that spinners may have to adapt themselves to a smaller proportion of the higher grades than they have enjyed of late years. "The visible supply of Amorican cotton is rapidly increasing, and now stands at 2,943,000 bales.

"In our circular of October 30 we stated our estimate of the American crop for 1906-7 definitely at 13,000,000 to 13,500,000 bales. The information which has reached us by mail and cable during the intervening three weeks would end us to increase rather than to reduce the total figure. It may turn out that we have been somewhat too sanguine as to the Atlantic States ; but, on the other hand, our experienced and judicious Texas correspondent, whom we quoted in our last circular as fally expecting 4,200,000 bales for that State and Indign Territory, and as considering 4,500, 00 quite possible, now raises his estimate to 4 3 0,000 bales, and he still fully maintains the possibility of 4,600,000.

"Another of our correspondents, fresh from a journey in that State, cables us in precisely the same sense. i.o., as to the certainty of a huge crop, and the possibility of 4,500,000. All this, we consider, fully offsets any danger of a smaller crop from the Atlantic than taken in our caloulation of October 30th, and encourages us to reiterate mort confidently our recent estimate of 13,000,000 to 13,500,000, as we now do.

During the past 23 working days since October 18), the amount gained has been 1,064.000 bales larger than last year, and even 262.000 larger than in the monster crop, year of 1914-5. Of this the gainings Rinoa October 31 have been no less than 1,689,060 bales, gsinst 1,015,000 last year (60 comparison being available of this item with 1914)."

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions- exppressed by our Correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limitts - free discussion.
"THE EGYPTIAN STANDARD."
CALIPH AND KAMEL.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,--The statements made by your Constantinople correspondent as to the suspicions that have been aroused at Stamboul by the notion of Mustapha Pasha Kamel in selecting "The Egyptian Standard" as the title of the new European organ of the Nationslist Party, are highly significant; as they show that the Sultan is at last waking up to the fact that the Egyptian Nationalists considerr Turkey as feeble a reed now-a-days on which to rest their hopes as France. Althongh the Arabic news papers attempted to throw dust in the eyes of their readers at the time, the inglorious, diplomatic defeat of the Sultan over the Tabah affair was a knock out blow to the few stalwarts who still hoped against hope that Turkey would regain her lost position in Egypt. The Nationalists think that the worst foes of a man are those of his own household and that it is far better to trust to the Radical and Home Role Members of Parliament to strike a blow at England, in Egypt than it is to rely on the procrastinating Turk or the excitable French deputy. I hear on very good authority that the question of Turkish support was discussed by thy founders of the "Egyatian Standard," and that it was decided that it would be far wiser policy to throw the Sultan overboard and go in for an out and out Nationallist policy, which would aim at the complete sevarance of Egypt from thue Ottoman Empire. So, instead of merely translating the title of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's Arabic organ "Al Lewa" (The Standard), it was decided to add a very significant addition and to call it "Tha Egyptian Standard," so as to show the world that the Ottoman flag was no longer recognised byy the Nationalists, and that tbeir aim was to bave a standard for Egypt I also have been informed that it was decided among the promoters of the new newspaper that this original line of policy should not be openly advocated and should only be koown to the inner ring of the party: Judging, however, from what your Constantinople corraspondent says, somebody has turned traitor and whispered at Yildiz the real significance of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's choice of name for his newspaper. His policy ought to please hit Radical allies in London, to whom the Sultan is as a red rag to a ball, and they will be delighted to lend their support to Mustapba Pasha Kamel, now that he can point to the "Egyptian Standard" as a proof of his, revolt from allegiance to the Sultan. It ought to be understood at Constantinople that the extreme Radicals in the House of Commons, who are now supporting Kamel, are the very same men who aid and abetthe Armenians against Turkey and, however astute the leader of the Egyptian Nationaliat Party may be, it is impossible for him to look for help from the Sultan when he is fraternining with Turky's bitter at foes in England. Be therefore hud to make a choice and he decided to call his newspapar the "Exyptian Standard" as a proof positive to his supporters in London that his friend wan Codlin, not Short.--Yours, etc,

div.head: MOSQUITOES AT HELOUAN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN Gazette."

Sir, I was glad to read in your issue of Friday last that stops are to be taken to exterminate mosquitoes at Helogan. I do not, however, think that filling up the ponds or parging them with petroleum will completely rid of of these pests, and I would suggest that the authorities should institute a house-to-honse visitation in order to exterminate the mosquito in their chief strongholds the native "z ers" and cesspools.

Anyone resident in Helouan at the present moment can testity to the fact that the mosquito post has assumed such proportions as to render, it practically impossible to pass the evening with any degree of comfort elsewhere than under a mosquito net. And this is felt to a much larger extent by those resident in houses in the town than by visitors to the hotels, which stand in their own grounds and well away from the ordinary dwelling houses.

We hear much these days of the many and great improvements which we are shortly to see at Holouan, and I would respectfully suggest to the anthorities that the fit and most important step should be the extermination of a pest, which has got far beyond the bounds of an ordinary discomfort, and the continuance of 'which cannot bot be detrimental to the welfare and development of the town.

A proper supply of filtered water would help greatly towards extermination of mosquitoes by rendering it unnecessary for hourse holders who do not possess filter tanks to make use of native 'zers" tor filtering purposes, but in the meantime, the anthorities will wall merit our gratitude if they begin the good work hy filling in or regularly purging the ponds and inducing house holders to take the necssary steps with regard to "zeors" and cesspools, -I am, etc,
RESIDENT Helonan, 2nd December,

div.head: Neglected Colds cause Consumption.
THE WHITE SCOURGE
div.p: MRS. ADDIE HARDING. MRS. MARY MEYER. MRS. FRANCES WILSON.
PROBABLY every case of consumption begins with a cold.
Consumption is generally classed as a hereditary disease, but consumption is not hereditary.
A constitutional weakness is inherited which renders one liable to consumption.
Even people who have strong lungs may acquire consumption from a cold.
Mrs. Addie Harding, 121 W, Brighton Ave., Syracuse, N. Y., writes:
"I have been a user of Peruna for the last twelve years and can truthfully say that there is no better medicine on earth.
"A SURE PREVENTATIVE."
"With me it is a sure preventative for colds and many other ills. In my home can always be found a bottle of Peruna. Two or three times a year I am troubled with my throat.
"I always had to have the services of my physician two or three times in each case.
"Although a user of Peruna, I never thought of taking it for my throat until about two years ago.
"I tried Peruna to check it, and to my great delight I was not troubled with the smothered and choked feeling and never have since.
"I can check it every time with Peruna.
"I certainly would not be without Peruna one minute."
Mrs. Mary Meyer, Thomson avenue, near Shell Road, Winfield, L. L, N. Y., writes:
"I have been annoyed with a cough for years.
"Often it was so bad that I could not sleep half the night. Many people thought I had consumption.
CONSUMPTION WAS FEARED.
"A woman recommended Peruna to me two years ago. I began to take Peruna and now I am perfectly free from a cough,
"I am glad to say that Peruna cured me entirely, I take Peruna occasionally when I do not feel well and I also give it to my children.
"Peruna is the best medicine for coughs and colds. I have told many people how much Peruna has helped me."
A neglected cold is a well-worn path to consumption.
Many a person catches cold and pays no attention to it.
He scarcely recovers from the first cold when he takes the second.
Still he gives it no heed, and possibly takes another cold, and so on.
He doses himself with bromides, quinine and various expectorants.
His case is catarrh, at this stage, and his case should be treated as catarrh.
A common cold is acute catarrh.
Finally, if the cold is allowed to continue, it becomes chronic catarrh.
Mrs, Frances Wilson, 82 Nelson street, Clinton, Mass., writes:
"Had you seen me at the time of my illness and now, you would not wonder that 1 take delight in sounding the praises of Peruna.
"My ailment was a severe cold which attacked the bronchial tubes and lungs.
"I followed your special directions and after using six bottles of Peruna I was on my feet again.
"I think Peruna a wonderful medicine."
All colds, coughs, bronchitis, laryngtis and tonsilitis should be treated as catarrh, as they are in reality catarrh.
The success of Peruna in relieving these cases entirely depends upon the fact that Peruna is a catarrh remedy.
It relieves catarrh wherever located in the system. Whether in the throat, bronchial tubes or lungs.
CONSUMPTION PREVENTED.
It has saved a multitude of peo-ple from consumption by eradicating catarrh before it reaches the lungs.
The tendency of catarrh of the throat or head is to spread downward to the lungs.
If taken in time, Peruna will prevent these cases.

We have in our files many testimonials from people who thought they were victims of consumption, but have been permanently relieved by the faithful use of Peruna. thus showing that catarrh was really the cause of their ailments.

For special directions everyone should read " The Ills of Life." a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES
AT PORT SUDAN.
The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender,
The ease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revise Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildlings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased or a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his contenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calcul. ated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to in spection at the following places during the usual business hours:
Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T). Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T)
Suakin: Office of Goveruor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director of Railways
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said : Othce of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative
London: *Office of Col. Western, Broad winy Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez : Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchaser's the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documentaton application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
"Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 6 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

[ABRIDGED PROSPECTUS,)

This Company has been formed for the purposes set out in its Morandum of association, and especially 10 carry on borinens in EXypt and the Soudan. The attention of the Board will as opportunities present themselves, be more particulary directed to :
1. The purchase, development and sequent leasing or re sale of agriculture nd boilding land.
2. The lending of money, on morte de or otherwise on land or other approves securities.

3. The carrying on of the business of an Investment Company. * The removal of all possibility of friction, dis to the Angle Frech, Agreement, and the confidence engendered, by be certainty if a protracted British administration, has added the element of stability to Egypt which it provionuly lacked.

That this vital faot is being realised i clearly shown by the remarkable progres Dos being made in agriculture and commerce which again is reflected in the ever-increas ing prosperity of the natives and the stead tine in valoe, of all property. While the rir o land valde doring the lagt few year has been remarkable, those who are bes acquainted with the conditions of the country. and its people are emphatically of the opinion that a furtherer steady inoreasee of prosperity and a corresponding improvement in values is assured.

The increasing wealth of the natives, whose one form of investment is agricultural land, coupled with the fact of their rapid numerical increase and the natúral limit imposed upon the cultivation of new land by the amonnt of water available for irrigation, all tend to in the capital and rental values of such is either actually under cultivation or is approaching that stage ; in addition to which, there always remains the fact that, even if the utmost possibilities foreshadowed by Sir William Garstin as to water supply were fulilled, it is estimated by Mr. Lang Anderson, that at most about another one and a half million acres could be brought into agricultnral use in the whole of Egypt, and that, only after an expenditure of over ten millions sterlirg during a period of twenty years. At the end of 1904, roughly five and a quarter million acres of land were held by about one million owners, of whom nearly seven eighths were native holders of less than five acres each. With an estimated present population of about eleven millions, which is steadily increasing at the rate of about 3 per cent per annumm, and with a revenue and a foreign trade which have increased over 60 and 100 per cant, respectively during the last 25 years it would uproar that the expression rised in Lord Cromer's Report of March last that "the material prosperity of the country rests on a basis of somewhat exceptional solidity" is amply justified.

In view of the facts above stated this Compary will mainly devote itself to the development of selected agricultural estates with a view to their rental or sale to natives in plots suitable to their requirements. Excellent opportunities frequently occur of lending money on fist mortgage at good rates and with an ample margin. With a local Advirory Board composed of business men of high standing and long experience in Egypt good profits may reasonably be expected from this and other forms of investment which require special local koowledge.
Mr. John Hicks Paull, the well-known Agricultural Expert in Egypt, he joined the Advisory Board, and will act as the Company's technical adviser for a period of three years.

The Company has acquired from The H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, the right to purchase the Kom-El Akhdar estate of 4,793 feddans (say 5 000 English acres), situated about 50 miles south of Alexandria, and connected by a tramway, 14 miles in length, with The Delta Light Railways system. Mr. R. Lang Anderson has reported to The H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, upon the property, and a copy of his Report is sent herewith.

It will be noted that he states that the supply of water appears to be excellent and the property well supplied with main canals. That the soil varies from a very light sandy loam to a heavy black loam, but is all suitable for cultivation of the usual crops of Lower Egypt. That the principal buildings are in excellent condition, and quite sufficient for the property at present but more accommodation for tenants will have to be built yearly as the land comes to the letting stase. That the number of working bullocks in sufficent for reclamation purposes, and there is a good supply of muless, horses, and donkeys for transport work. The general crops of cotton, berneem, wheat, and barley were doing well. That the property was capable of great development at moderate cost, and if £30,000 were judiciously spent on it during the next five years it could be brought to a capital value of £75 to £80 per feddan. That the work of development is simple and follows well known lines, so that the element of nonforeign contingencies was largely diminished while the results of development were, sure. That he advises the property is a good investment at £15 per foddan, and confidently recommends the purchase. That if money on development is well spent, the capital value will increase enormously yearly. That the present rental receiver is L.B.2,841 60^(=£3.940) sterling), but is £4 per ferdan in respect of 980 feddans let, and he states that in his opinion, when fully reclaimed, the whole of the property should let at a even better rent-4793 feddans at, say, £1 10% per feddan, would give an income of £21,500 per annum.
The H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, have obtained an option on a valuable property, of about 55,000 metres, at Rhoda Island, Cairo, which can be secured by this Company at a satisfactory price.
The Directors have other business in view which is believed to be of a mot profitable nature ; * however, negotiations are still in progress, it is not possible to give details at present.
Full detail, &c., can be obtained by intending applicants at the Anglo Egyptian Bank.
OF Mr. R. LANG ANDERSON'S REPORT.
15, RUE DE LA GARE DE RAMLEN,
ALEXANDRIE,
EGYPT, 24th May 1906.
DEAR SIK,
KOM-EL-AHDAR PROPERTY.
Having visited the Kun-ul Ahdar property, I beg to report as follows:

SITUATION - The property is well situated and eassily got at, being about 50 miles southeast of Alexandria and only 1 1/2 miles distant from Kom-el-Ahdar Station on the Delta Light Railway, from which point there is a 60 centimetre tramway to the principal homestead.
IRRIGATION -- The supply of water appeared to be excellent, and the property is well supplied with main canals.

DRAINAGE on the greater part of the Estate is good, but the drains are too few in number And not deep enough. The whole property would greatly benefit, in my opinion, by a closer and deeper system of canalisation. About 1,000 feddans, more or less, are comparatively low lying and may require to have their drainage pumped during part of the year to reclaim them properly.

SOIL varies from a very light sandy loam to a heavy black loam, but is all suitable for cultivation of the usual crops of Lower Egypt. BUILDINGS --The principal buildings, which are in excellent condition, are quite sufficient for the property, but more accommodation for tenants will have to be built yearly as the land comes to the letting stage.
STOCK.- The number of working bullocks is sufficient for reclamation purposes, and there is a good supply of moles, horses, and donkeys for tbe transport work.

PRESENT CONDITION. The usual crops of cotton, berseem, wheat, and barley are doing well, and on the high light soil all round the principal dwelling house, orange and lemon trees would grow well. On several parts of the Estate the cotton was looking very well, but on other parts it was doing badly, simply due, in my opinion, to having been planted on land not yet sufficiently reclaimed to grow the crop. Rice was being grown as a reclamation crop, and would do better if the drains were closer and deeper and the land more carefully levelled before the crop was sown.

FUTURE DEVELOPMENT. The property is capable of great development at moderate cost. If £80,000 is judiciously spent on it during the next three years, it can be brought to a capital value of £75 to £80 per feddan. The work of development is simple and follows well known lines, so that the element of unforeseen contingencies is largely diminished, while the results off development are sure.

CONCLUSION.- The property is a good investment at £15 a feddan. The revenue for the first year or two will be small, but if the money on development is well spent the capital value will be increasing enormously yearly, and later on the revenge will come in and go on increasing until at least £4 10.s, is reached. I can confidently recommend the purchase of this Estate of 4.793 feddans, which, acoording to Mr. Sursock's figures, has at present a rental of L.E. 3,841.600 from an area of 980 feddans let, which is slightly over £4 sterling per feddar, and I see no reason why the whole of the property, when fully reclaimed, should not do even better, as some of the let land is not, in my opinion, quite ready to give to tenants, and if the proprietor had kept it in his own hands for another year under reclamation crops he could have got a higher reut.
Yonrg faithfully,
(Signed) R. LANG ANDERSON C. T. HOLLAND E q..
THE H. AND J. SYNDICATE LIMITED..
VALUATION OF KOM-EL-AHDAR.
GROSS AREA 4,793 FEDDANS.

All buildings, machinery, live stock, and other assets, being essential to the property, are included in the above valuation. The area, of the diffrent classes are taken from Mr. Sursocks figures. The Half Canal Francaouia is a very valuable asset, but not being lettable I have put no value against it. The land tax (payable to Government varies from P.T. 5 to P.T. 57 per feddan, and, acsording to Mr. Sursock's figures, amounts at present to L.E. 653 646 mills which is not heavy, as land tax runs, being only an average of PT. 13 3,5 per feddan, but this, of course, will be increased as the land is reclaimed.
R. L. A.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the varions market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Snbscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This Company has been formed for the purpose set out in its Memorandum of Association; to carry on business in Eypt and the Sudan, and more particularly to develop the well-known health resort of Helouan, near Cairo, by the acquisition of Land and Building sites, and by the erection of Buildings thereon, and generally with the object of acquiring interests of divers kinds in this rapidly improving district.

Although facilities for the acquisition of properties in Helogan will it is believed be afforded the Directors, yet no existing or proposed contracts to be entered into by the Co. on its inception are in force.

It is unnecessary to point out the paramount position held by Helouan as a health and pleasare resort, as the fame of its curative mineral springs and delightful climatic conditions are so well known and appreciated. But what is interesting to know, from a commercial point of view, is that the rapid growth of Helouan has attracted the attention of investors to the opportunities that now offer for the remunerative employment of capital in its development.

Helogan is situate about 16 miles from Cairo, and is connected by the Egyptian Delta. Light Railways, Limited, the directors of which are 80 alive to the future of this rising suburb of Cairo, that they have or are about to expend £60,000 in improving this branch of their lipn. The line to Tourah was recently doubled, thas accelerating the communication and enabling the Company, to put on a frequent service of Express Trains, (the journey oocupying about 30 minutes). The passenger service has already been equipped with luxurious modern corridor carriages fitted with Electric Light.

Helouan is becoming increasingly popular as a residential district for Cirt professional and business men, and a growing demand is apparent for more improved and commodious habitations than at present exist.

The yearly influx of visitors steadiliy paes, hotel and other residential establishments are feeling the tax on their resource to adaquately meet the requirements of those jug the health-giving adyantages of He desert air.
The Golf Links, Racecourse, Paddock, Racing Stables, etc., are important attractions, and the surroundings afford the most enjoyable place for horse exercice near Cairo.
The following is given in compliance wih the requirements of the Companies Act, 1900.

By a contract dated 17th November, 1906, and made between Andrew Percy Phillips on behalf of the Company and the Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, who are in consideration of paying all the costs, charges and expenses of and incident to the preparatoation, executing, stamping and registration of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the preparation, advertising, printing and the circnlating of the prospectus, and all charges and legal expenses up to and including date of allotment, exclusive of stamps on Share Warrants, or any brokerage in respect of such capital, to receive a sum of seven thousand five hundred pounds from the Company.

The Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, has further undertaken to underwrite, for a commission of five per cent, payable by the Company, eighty five thousand Shares of £1 each. This contract will be adopted by the Company.
Various sub underwriting contracts exist:--
Two Directors, Mr. Elie Toriel and Mr. J. Robert Campbell are interested in the production of the Company to the extent of 500 s each in the Egyptian Lands and Agency ted.
The Directors are interested underwriters, and each will receive the five per cent. on the number of shares underwritten by him as follows:--
Elia Toriel, 5 000 shares. J. Ropart Campbel, 2.000 shares. Augaste Rossano, 3,000 share. Alfred Chamass, 3,000 shares, and Edward Forti 2,000 shares.

Applications for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no alloment is made, the application money will be returned in fall, and where the number of shares alloted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction to the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failare to pay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.
A copy of the Memorandam of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.
The minimum snbscription upon which the Diretors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association et £100.000.

No claims for brokerage will be recognised by tbe Company unless the Application Form is distinctly stamped with the name and address of Brokers whose clients are subscribing.

div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above named Copamy will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, EC., on Friday, the fourteenth day of December 1906, it 12.30 o'clock in the afternoon for the purpose of considering and if deemed advisable passing the subjoined Resolution with or without modification.

Should the Resolution be passed by the required majority it will be subimitted for confirmation as a Special Resolution to a second Extraordinary General Meeting which will be subsequently convened. By Order of the Board,
L HALLIDAY.
Secretary.
Dated this 23rd day of November 1906; 19.72 Bishopsgate Street Within, London, E.C.
RESOLUTION.
That the Articles of Association be altered in manner following: -- .
(a) The following articles shall be inserted after Article II, namely:

11 a, Upon any offer of shared to the public for subscription the Company may pay a commission of not more than 7% on the shares so offered to any person in consideration of his subscribing or agreeing to subscribe whether absolutely or conditionally for any shares in the Company or procuring or agreeing to procure subscriptions whether absolute or conditional for any shares in the Company.
11 b. Upon any offer of shares to the public for subscription the amount payable upon application on each share offered shall not be less than 5 per cent of the nominal amount of the share.

(b) In Article 42 b. the sentence beginning with the words "the holder" down to and including the words "of such warrant" shall be cancelled and in lieu thereof the following sentence shall be substituted "Unless otherwise " determined the following conditions shall " have effect as to share warrants." .
(c). In Article 42 b (XIV) the word "three" shall be altered to "live" and the following words shall be inserted after the words "at the office of the Company," namely :-

or at such other place in London as the Directors may fix by advertisement or "unless 10 days at least before the day appointed for the meeting in the first case or before the requisition is left at the office in the second case he shall have deposited "the share warrant at the office in Alexendria of the Company or at such other place in Alexandria as the Directors shall from time to time fix by advertisement in the "Times" newspaper and some newspaper published or circulating in Alexandria" and after the word "together" the following words shall be inserted, namely "in any of the foregoing cases."
(d). The following clauses shall be inserted in Article 425, namely:

(xvii a). Fourteen days' notice at the least specifying the time and place fixed for any general meeting and in case of special business the general nature of such business shall be given to bearers of share warrants by advertisement in manner hereinafter provided.

(xvii b). Any notice required to be or which may be given to bearers of share warrants shall be sufficiently given if advertised once in "The Times" and once in at least one newspaper published or circulating in Alexandria.

le). In Article 53 there shall be inserted after the words "shall be given" the following words, namely, "to members holding registered shares" and before the word "member" in each place where that word occurs shall be added the word "such."
(f). In Article 137 there shall be inserted after the werd "Member" where that word first occurs the words "holding registered shares."
